title: Situated Multi-Modal Interaction
segmentation: Right, so I want to thank Rainer, Rainer for talking about Chill and some of the early projects since I saw that I was following Reiner and talking to a lot of my ex friends from chill, I put a subtitle chill 10 years later.
Specifically, I want to talk about one of the components that we developed in chill or the situation models.
This is a slide that we used quite a bit during the CHILL project.
This was actually made by our friends in Prague.
I'm trying to remember the guys name the engineers at IBM who latched onto the technique with us and developed it quite a bit.
As you can see the situation model in Red was at the heart of the chill multimodal services and in.
Fact when we built the chill system, we started by building the situation model with simulations for the upper for the services and the perceptual components.
And then we built out.
So the situation model really was at the heart, but at the time we saw it as an engineering tool we didn't really ask what were the theoretical foundations for it.
Was there a previous literature?
I'm going to go back now and visit some of that and tell you about what the science from cognitive science from ergonomics and from other domains like that behind the situation water was.
So.
We start by talking about situation models.
This is actually a technique that's been used in cognitive psychology since the 80s.
OK, Philip Johnson Laird and his students have applied this technique too.
Variety of domains.
They use it as a.

A model for providing context for story understanding for describing human abilities to provide context for story understanding to interpret ambiguous and misleading perceptions, to reason with default information.
To focus attention.
You can find their work in in natural language.
Understanding in written text, understanding in just a whole variety of cognitive science domains and what we've been doing with chilan.
Then, since Chill was to use this technique as a software framework for services.
But also do these things.
So.

Essentially, as with the chill model, the situation model sits between the services and perception action components that drive sensors and actuators, and it describes relevant actors and objects for services.
It filters events and it basically directs the operation of the system.
So let me let me get a little bit technical.
I took the equations out.
I also had took a lot of the eye candy out to fit into 15 minutes, but technically a situation is a set of relations between entities.
Computer scientists recognize that as a state.
Indeed it's a state to kind of directed state graph entities or anything we can observe.
Any observable phenomena that can be people, things, time, places, events a day can be an entity properties or the attributes that describe entities and relations.
Our truth functions now back during chill we use Boolean relations.
We do these logically, but over the last six or seven years we found that we can do a lot more with probabilistic relations using Bayesian graph Nets, Bayesian graphs and probabilistic graphs.

And behaviors or event condition actions that you can attach to the individual situations to the States and they describe not only what happens externally in acting with the external world or with people, but also what happens internally 'cause they can direct the logic of control of the system.
The situation graph is both an internal model for how the system should behave internally and an external model for how it behaves with the world.
So we have a situation graph.
It's a network of situations with transition conditions.
And in each situation there's a set of entities to observe an actions to take.
And well, in our group we define a context model as a specific set of situations, entities, relations and behaviors.
Now this has been used in a large variety of systems.
Of course we used it even before chill as a privacy filter for a media space.
We used it in fame.
Those of you who were around when we did the fame project may remember there was a situation model driving the intelligent cameraman.
It was.
It's also been used for assisted living with elderly people in Casper and more recently with for polite social interaction with robots and Remy Barracones work in show.
We used it as a memory jog context aware mobile phone Manager, meeting, minute recorder, and more.
Recently I've seen a similar technique used for logistics management.
An for hospital health care.

OK, so just as a quick quick example, I took the film out to save time, but the situation model sits between, for example, the meeting minute recorder and the perceptual components which can be combined in a sort of a Federation, hierarchical or others.
Well, for example, one of the films I was going to show shows people talking around a table and records who's talking now.
Interesting things that was important in that was to know the idea of role.
When someone is speaking, they're taking a certain role in the meeting and you can understand what they're allowed to do and not to do and what the system should do with respect to them.
Based on that concept of role.
Well, it turns out that role also enables machine learning and reasoning by analogy.
So very powerful concept, but a little bit subtle.
We compare them to Skolem functions.
In logic, it's a function which replaces a variable with another variable, but in a very limited set.
So some examples of applications where the meeting minute recorder, at least our version of it is now commercialized by a company called Meaningful.
Video surveillance we've used similar techniques for watching customers in stores and boy video.
Customer monitoring before high Labs failed a year or two ago they were using this to understand what people were doing in front of an interactive store window.

We've used it for active, active, active military, an elderly monitoring for socially where computer interaction of course, and most recently with a startup company building context aware services in smartphones that monitors your activity 24/7 I want.
Just say just a word about this.
'cause this is a really exciting project for me.
This isn't a software component that we add into apps.
To provide the right information at the right time, what it does essentially is it monitor activity 24/7.
With an initial model about the human daily cycle and then it associates activities with semantic locations, semantic time and it learns routines.

And from that it can predict what's going to happen next, and it can propose information and services OK. And actually, that's turning out to be very exciting, and I think this will be coming very soon to your phone.
Now, of course, you could worry it's going to drain my battery, and we're very aware of that.
We use autonomic techniques as we did with chill to control the resources so that we comply.

The available resources I had wanted to say a word about software components and I had a library of several 100 movies like Reiner was showing of different components that were built up in children afterwards doing much the same thing he was showing, but I think to save time I'm just going to show.
So the idea the theoretical idea was one of transformation.
Taking observation into an observation as a dataflow architecture under control of some kind of controller.
And the architecture that we built there, we continue to use.
We have a component controller, so the component is autonomous.
OK, we have a number of observation modules and we select them on the fly during each cycle to re estimate the parameters of the entities and then give interpretation.
Now we've recently in a national project, taking this into mobile devices.
Working with St. We put this onto your smartphone right at the right now.
Partly in Silicon so that we can do vision in real time without using up all the computational resources.

Now you can also do that without the SD hardware and do it now in the processing and a lot of the emotion recognition face tracking stuff that Reiner showed we have running on mobile devices and tablets and there is a real market for that stuff.
OK, I'm going to skip this.
I was going to say.
Some things about component monitoring from this very old 2008 film.

Essentially, this was illustrating the idea that one component finds the body and then the fact of having found the body drives a different kind of component with different observation routines to find the hands, and then they can drive components, define the orientation of the face to get face expression, etc.
So one the output from one drives and.
But that's gotta be pretty standard stuff now.
The hard problem.
One of the expensive things is where is the situation model come from now?
Up through chill, we were handcrafting them.
We were essentially building them by hand and that's a very expensive in differ.
What process?
Following chill.
We had a series of doctoral theses that tried to do that automatically.
One of them.
Have Remy Barakel set out to train.
I bow to be polite.
The AIBO robot comes with about 200 pre programmed behaviors but I bow has no kind of an idea of when they are appropriate or not and so I both.
Basic logic is if he hears people he tries to play and be cute which can be really, really annoying if you're trying to talk on the phone.
So I live with an I bow.

I have one in my office now I've taken it home and it sits at home and the challenge for me was to make Aibo do the right thing at the right time, which meant understanding who was in the room and what they were doing.

So what he did, what we did was to build a feedback system based on caressing or tapping the head of the aibo's feedback and then do reinforcement learning to learn the appropriateness and inappropriateness of behaviors for each situation.
Now there's a lot more to learning than just that.
In particular, we need to learn to recognize the entities we need to learn what the states are.
I put a few words about that in here.
Basically, what we've been doing more and more is using failure of prediction as an automatic feedback for reinforcement learning and further learning techniques.
An imp.
Particular, the probabilistic situation models, combined with graph models.
Have proved really useful for learning the state model for situations and for adapting and developing state models.
So essentially the technique we give is we have a very rudimentary, simple situation model.
We put it out, deploy it, interacting with people, and as it fails it grows new situations.
And as it becomes confident, it starts acting OK when it when it sees that it can predict successfully what's happening and that what it predicts predicts is the behavior it shows was correct.
It starts using the behaviors.
When it fails, it tries other things.
It's A kind of feet of.
I guess you could compare it in some way to genetic programming, but it's not using just.
Things like decision trees.
Great, I'm on time.
ID 3 An the old decision tree algorithms from the 1980s have turned out to be really useful for this.
I was surprised.
Go back and use the Seaport 4.5 and and compare it to some of the other decision trees and it's the one that's that and random forests that are giving us interest.
Results.
Um?
This is all fine, but what we want is situated interaction an I think we tend to forget what that means.
Let me talk just a little bit about Lucy Suchman.
Situated interaction is the study of interaction between an agent and the environment and the core concept is one of mediation.
Situated interaction emphasizes emergent contingent.
Action and activity.
The environment is part of the cognitive process.
It is search that plans are artifacts of reasoning that people.
Invent after the fact to explain what they were doing or to communicate.
But then in fact most people don't work pre.
With preplanned plans, unless you've communicated procedural knowledge to them and they're following the procedure, but even then the execution of the procedure tends to be emergent and contingent.
Or, unless they've operationalized, and when you operationalize, you're you've programmed a sequence of steps into a program step that you execute reflexively.

And when it fails you UN program it so we have to remember that really what we want is not to do blind complex plans and hope that they turn out with the world, but that the world is part of our cognitive process.
Now to do that.
We have to have attention and there's a lot of study of attention that comes from ergonomics.
People who fly airplanes or helicopters are very concerned about human factors, and you can.
We can talk to our pilot friends about human factors, and many of them recognize the ideas and the concepts from people like Endsley.
We
You've used that to build up a architecture.
Inspired by Endsley's work that structures a process model that does detection and assimilation of observations, projects forward in time to what's going to happen.
Anticipates problems that are about to happen.
Makes decisions about what to do and then does focused, directed attention to perceive what's going on in the world or to act.
And I had some examples also of systems there, but for 15 minutes well.
So let me conclude.
With a few of the things we've learned since Chill.
Situation models provide an enabling con technology.
For context aware systems, I think I've tried to make that clear to this morning.
Probabilistic graph models and decision trees provide effective techniques for learning and reasoning with uncertainty.
Situation models can be acquired by development and adaptation driven by interaction.
An adaptation requires robust perception.

We need these perceptual components to work with error rates down below 5% in order to learn from them, because if the perception and action are introducing errors into your learning process, things don't work very well.
And situation models can be developed using decision trees.
Right so I.
I hope I kept a 15 minutes.
I'd like to respect time absolutely.
Some of the bibliography I cited can be found here, but there's a lot more.
OK, so thank you all very much.
Thank you.
